tool.name: ViewshedAlongPath

param.name: in_raster
param.dialogReference:
Input elevation raster.

This is the input elevation raster which is used in the viewshed computation.
param.pythonReference:
Input elevation raster.

This is the input elevation raster which is used in the viewshed computation.

param.name: in_polyline_feature
param.dialogReference:
The input polyline feature class that typically represents the route along which the observer moves. The direction of the movement follows the order of the vertices of the polyline.

The vertices of the polyline are used as observation locations in the viewshed computation.
param.pythonReference:
The input polyline feature class that typically represents the route along which the observer moves. The direction of the movement follows the order of the vertices of the polyline.

The vertices of the polyline are used as observation locations in the viewshed computation.

param.name: out_raster
param.dialogReference:
The output visibility raster.

The output will only record the number of times that each cell location in the input surface raster can be seen by the input observation points (or vertices for polylines). The observation frequency will be recorded in the VALUE item in the output raster's attribute table.
param.pythonReference:
The output visibility raster.

The output will only record the number of times that each cell location in the input surface raster can be seen by the input observation points (or vertices for polylines). The observation frequency will be recorded in the VALUE item in the output raster's attribute table.

param.name: out_point_features
param.dialogReference: The locations of the polyline vertices which are used in the viewshed computation.
param.pythonReference: The locations of the polyline vertices which are used in the viewshed computation.

param.name: z_factor
param.dialogReference:
Number of ground x,y units in one surface z unit.

The z-factor adjusts the units of measure for the z units when they are different from the x,y units of the input surface. The z-values of the input surface are multiplied by the z-factor when calculating the final output surface.

If the x,y units and z units are in the same units of measure, the z-factor is 1. This is the default.

If the x,y units and z units are in different units of measure, the z-factor must be set to the appropriate factor, or the results will be incorrect. For example, if your z units are feet and your x,y units are meters, you would use a z-factor of 0.3048 to convert your z units from feet to meters (1 foot = 0.3048 meter).
param.pythonReference:
Number of ground x,y units in one surface z unit.

The z-factor adjusts the units of measure for the z units when they are different from the x,y units of the input surface. The z-values of the input surface are multiplied by the z-factor when calculating the final output surface.

If the x,y units and z units are in the same units of measure, the z-factor is 1. This is the default.

If the x,y units and z units are in different units of measure, the z-factor must be set to the appropriate factor, or the results will be incorrect. For example, if your z units are feet and your x,y units are meters, you would use a z-factor of 0.3048 to convert your z units from feet to meters (1 foot = 0.3048 meter).

param.name: densify_distance
param.dialogReference: This parameter allows you to increase the density of vertices on the polyline feature in a regular interval. Each vertice will be used as an observer location in the viewshed computation.
param.pythonReference: This parameter allows you to increase the density of vertices on the polyline feature in a regular interval. Each vertice will be used as an observer location in the viewshed computation.

param.name: observer_offset
param.dialogReference: This value will be added to the observer elevation before the viewshed computation. The default value is 1.
param.pythonReference: This value will be added to the observer elevation before the viewshed computation. The default value is 1.

param.name: inner_radius
param.dialogReference: The inner radius defines the minimum visible distance to be considered. When the value is greater than 0, the areas within this distance are not visible by the observer.
param.pythonReference: The inner radius defines the minimum visible distance to be considered. When the value is greater than 0, the areas within this distance are not visible by the observer.

param.name: outer_radius
param.dialogReference: The outer radius defines the maximum visible distance to be considered. Areas beyond this distance are considered to be not visible by the observer.
param.pythonReference: The outer radius defines the maximum visible distance to be considered. Areas beyond this distance are considered to be not visible by the observer.

param.name: horizontal_range
param.dialogReference:
The horizontal scan range of the observer's line of sight.

It should be specified as degrees from 0 to 360. The default value is 60.
param.pythonReference:
The horizontal scan range of the observer's line of sight.

It should be specified as degrees from 0 to 360. The default value is 60.

param.dialogReference:
The vertical upper limit of the scan range of the observer's line of sight.

It should be specified as degrees from 0 to 90. The default value is 30.

tool.summary: Calculates a visibility surface along a route assuming that the observer moves along the route in a certain direction and the line of sight is subject to the restriction of a cone of vision.
tool.usage:
• This tool requires a Spatial Analyst license.

  • The input polyline feature represents the route that the observer moves along. The direction of the movement follows the order of the vertices of the polyline.

  • The visibility computation uses the vertices of the input polyline feature as observation locations. The vertices should be dense enough to provide a meaningful number of observation locations. You can increase the density of vertices by specifying a value for the Polyline Vertices Densification Distance parameter.

  • The observation locations can be saved out as a point feature class through the Output point features parameter.

  • If the input raster contains undesirable noise caused by sampling errors, you can smooth the raster with a low-pass filter, such as the Mean option of Focal Statistics, before running this tool.

  • Determining visibility is a computer-intensive process. The processing time is dependent on the resolution. For preliminary studies, you may want to use a version of the suface raster with a coarser cell size to reduce the number of cells in the input. Use the full resolution raster when the final results are ready to be generated.

  • To speed up the visibility analysis process, you can use the Extent and Mask environment settings to restrict the analysis to a smaller area. For example, first use the Buffer tool to create a polygon around the input polyline feature, using your intended outer radius value as the buffer distance. Then, set the Extent and Mask environments to the buffer output you just created.

  • The following environment settings affect this tool:

    • General: Current Workspace, Scratch Workspace, Output Coordinate System, Extent, Snap Raster.

    • Raster analysis: Cell Size, Mask.

scriptExample.title: ViewshedAlongPath example (Python window)
scriptExample.para: This example computes a visibility surface from a polyline feature, assuming the observer moves along the polyline.
scriptExample.code:
#Add toolbox to arcpy arcpy.env.workspace = r"c:\ToolData" arcpy.AddToolbox(r"C:\pythontoolbox\Spatial Analyst Supplemental Tools.pyt")
#Execute ViewshedAlongPath tool arcpy.ViewshedAlongPath_sas("elevation","path2.shp","outvsd1", "#", 1, "#", 1, 0, 2000, 60, 30, -30)

scriptExample.title: ViewshedAlongPath example (Stand-alone script)
scriptExample.para: This example computes a visibility surface from a polyline feature, assuming the observer moves along the polyline.
scriptExample.code:
#Add toolbox to arcpy arcpy.CheckOutExtension("spatial") arcpy.env.workspace = r"c:\ToolData"
inSurface = "elevation" inPolyline = "path2.shp" outRaster = "outvsd2" outPoints = "outpnt.shp" zFactor = 1.0 densDistance = "#" obsOffset = 1 inRadius = 0 outRadius = 2000 horizSpan = 60 vertUpperAngle = 30 vertLowerAngle = -30
arcpy.AddToolbox(r"C:\pythontoolbox\Spatial Analyst Supplemental Tools.pyt")
#Execute ViewshedAlongPath tool arcpy.ViewshedAlongPath_sas(inSurface, inPolyline, outRaster, outPoints, zFactor, densDistance, obsOffset, inRadius, outRadius, horizSpan, vertUpperAngle, vertLowerAngle)
